properties.Title: Fog Advisory In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Near zero visibility in fog is occurring over some areas. Dense areas of fog have developed and are expected to persist early this morning. Fog will dissipate this morning after sunrise. ### Visibility may be significantly and suddenly reduced to near zero. Travel is expected to be hazardous due to reduced visibility in some locations. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: More rain is expected in association with the remnants of Post-Tropical Storm Teddy. Additional rainfall: 5 to 15 mm. Time span: continuing until later this morning. Locations: southeastern Labrador. Remarks: Rain, heavy at times over some areas, will taper off later this morning. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: A low pressure system approaching Baffin Island will bring gusty easterly winds to the Pangnirtung region tonight and Thursday. Winds will gradually increase this evening gusting to near 80 km/h overnight. In the vicinity of the higher terrain surrounding the community, wind gusts may possibly exceed 100 km/h. Strong winds will persist into Thursday morning but gradually moderate in the afternoon before diminishing further Thursday evening. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NUstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NUStorm.
Expires: 2020-09-24T15:58:09-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-09-23T23:59:09-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.1650421355.2020
Area: Pangnirtung
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Wind Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Strong winds that may cause damage are expected or occurring. A fast moving low pressure system will cross northern Vancouver Island late tonight. Ahead of the low, strong southerly winds of 60 to 90 km/h will develop over western Vancouver Island overnight. Winds will peak late tonight or early Friday morning, before shifting to westerly and easing Friday as the low moves inland. ### High winds may toss loose objects or cause tree branches to break. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to BCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #BCStorm.
Expires: 2020-09-25T03:54:16-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-09-24T11:55:16-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.3583016862.2020
Area: West Vancouver Island
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Rainfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Rain, at times heavy, is expected. A moist and unstable airmass will continue bring bands of heavy showers across Howe Sound, the Fraser Valley, and northern sections of Metro Vancouver through this morning. A risk of thunderstorms embedded in this system may further lead to brief, intense, localized downpours. Over the region, 35 to over 100 mm have fallen since Wednesday morning. Additional rainfall amounts of 20 to 30 mm are expected today. The heavy showers are expected to ease somewhat this afternoon. However, rain will redevelop tonight as the next system approaches the region. ### Heavy downpours can cause flash floods and water pooling on roads. Rainfall warnings are issued when significant rainfall is expected. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to BCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #BCStorm.
Expires: 2020-09-25T01:59:56-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-09-24T11:51:56-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.1679664818.2020

properties.Title: Tropical Cyclone Information Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: For Post-tropical Storm Teddy. This is the final statement for this storm. Post-Tropical Storm Teddy continues northeastward into the Strait of Belle Isle and will merge with a larger extratropical low over the Labrador Sea on Thursday. 1. Summary of basic information at 12:30 P.M. NDT. Location: 51.0 north 57.3 west. About 90 kilometers west-southwest of St. Anthony. Maximum sustained winds: 85 kilometers per hour. Present movement: north-northeast at 50 kilometers per hour. Estimated minimum central pressure: 975 millibars. 2. Summary of latest information. Teddy continues to produce strong southerly winds over the western coast of Newfoundland as the centre tracks towards southeastern Labrador. 3 to 5 metres waves are expected to continue over the southern and eastern Atlantic marine waters into Thursday morning. Forecaster(s): McArthur ### Please continue to monitor alerts issued by the Canadian Hurricane Centre and forecasts issued by Environment Canada.
Expires: 2020-09-24T19:59:00-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-09-24T02:55:00-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.2300254085.2020
Area: Burgeo - Ramea, Channel-Port aux Basques and vicinity
properties.Author: Environment Canada
